>>91049085
ChatGPT is so named because it's built for chat, the rest are not really "bots" and not built for ease of use, they are more obviously the text prediction/completion engines that all LLMs really are. by which i mean the normal way to use them is write "The colours on the french flag are " and it'll complete the sentence, you can also have it complete text by predicting what comes after "What colours are on the french flag?" or even simulate chat but it's worse at it because (1) it's slightly more layers of abstraction to deal with that it's not finetuned for, and (2) ChatGPT is just the beefiest model by far, AFAIK the most powerful expensive iteration of GPT3 is still mogged pretty hard by ChatGPT which is semi-informally called "GPT3.5". I think that's the terminology anyway.

Before asking for help, please check our list of resources.

posts.com:
>>91010549
It's for "managing farms of symbolic links"
>t.manual

In all seriousness it's useful for managing config files. I don't want my entire ~/.config directory to be a git repo, but I still want to VC some programs' configs. But then some are in ~/.config, ~/.programname{.d}/rcfile and some are just plain ~/.programrc files.
so I instead use stow to have all important packages in a separate directory.
This way I can have awesomewm's files (~/.config/awesome) and zsh's (~/.zshrc) files in one easy to manage directory.
You can do other stuff with it too, but I just use the basic features.

>>91014132
You don't need them if you don't want them. binfmt is the kernels mechanism for registering binaries as an entrypoint for foreign architectures.

For example you can register Qemu to run ARM applications on an X86 system and the kernel will hand any ARM binaries it sees to Qemu to emulate.

I would leave it alone if I were you. It doesn't cause any harm.

posts.com:

part.
Otherwise you'll need to do the more work intensive thing using one of these tools here.
https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/File_recovery
Ext4magic seems like it would work for you, but I haven't used any of them so I can't say for certain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91016305
>>91016175
Or actually, maybe testdisk instead of ext4magic, testdisk is reportedly for whole partitions. But I'd suggest starting with the e2fsck part section https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/File_recovery#e2fsck
At the very least let this be a (painful) lesson in keeping backups, it's worth the effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91016259
Depends on what you mean.
Dual booting doesn't really apply when you're talking about just adding another storage device. That's just running another OS, it's "safe" in the sense that unless you majorly fuck up the OSs shouldn't render each other unbootable but malware is malware and shit happens.
If you want to truly be safe get a hotswap bay and swap drives for airgap isolation. Won't protect you against glowies, but it'll stop you from accidentally formatting your Linux drive while in Windows. Windows loves to prompt you "You need to format this drive..." on shit it can't read, and that's a mistake waiting to happen if you ever enter disk management with your Linux drive still connected to the system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91012142
Happened the same to me, I put this in /etc/tmpfiles.d/local.conf
w /sys/kernel/mm/transparent_hugepage/enabled - - - - madvise
w /sys/kernel/mm/transparent_hugepage/defrag - - - - madvise

It disables hugepages unless the program itself requests (madvise) it. By default this is set to always.
I haven't had any problems since changing this and the problem is now gone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91016259
There's no danger, if you take your time. If you rush or you don't read properly, you might just format your linux drives instead of the empty partition. Make sure you click on the partition you're going to use for windows, and nothing else bad will happen to your computer. You should recognise it by the size of it and make sure it's selected.

Afterwards, you're not going to get weird prompts about formatting your ext4 partitions. I think a lot of people think Windows is going to treat them like unformatted USB drive and ask you about formatting them with fat as you log in, but in reality, they just sit in disk management until you decide to do something with them.

At least in windows 10, that's what you can expect

>>91047622
BTRFS subvolumes are quite different from a volume group or ZFS. They are more like folders that you can mount, not virtual partitions containing their own filesystems.
I went this way because the swapfile wouldn't work properly in BTRFS - maybe related to OpenRC. I also needed hibernation which is pretty complicated to get working under BTRFS.
How's ZFS on linux these days? I might give this a try since it has all these things including encryption integrated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91047825
Swap files work with BTRFS you just have to follow a specific procedure to make them.
You only need a swap partition if you use hibernation and you don't LVM unless you're constantly re-sizing your swap partition for some reason.

Never. The move to Apple Silicon is the best thing to happen to the Mac in a decade. The last few generations of Intel MacBooks were absolutely straining with the heat output.

>>91033074
Agreed on the general decline in software quality, but that might at least partially be chalked up to the multiple foundational transitions that macOS has been undergoing for the past few years (HFS+ > APFS, Objective-C > Swift, Carbon+Cocoa(AppKit) > Catalyst+SwiftUI, OpenGL+OpenCL > Metal, and x86 > ARM).

There was also a period from about 2012 to 2020 where it felt like Apple had seriously lost interest in developing the Mac any further as its own unique platform, and had sorta put it into maintenance mode while it focused on its other product lines. The fact that it sold laptops for YEARS with the faulty butterfly-switch keyboard and that stupid fucking Touch Bar did little to assuage those concerns. But I've been mostly pretty happy with the direction things have been going in since 2020, and for the first time in years Apple seems to genuinely give a shit about the Mac and what makes it unique compared to, say, the iPad, while introducing interesting new ways for the two to work together (Sidecar, Universal Control, etc).

I still don't see a fucking point in slapping a touchscreen on a MacBook when there's already a nice big trackpad for scrolling, zooming, and other gestures. Not to mention, as you said, that macOS's UI is built for pixel-precision control, not finger-sized touch targets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048978
There are very few mainstream individual brands that are blanket good or bad. I would argue asrock is probably one of the weakest of the bigger manufacturers, but they don’t really make anything inherently bad, it’s just their “good” isn’t up to par with everyone else.
Their premium motherboard line being the Taichi stuff isn’t at the same level as something such as the Asus rog crosshair, gigabyte aorus extreme, msi godlike, etc

If you want the best parts you’d be buying any major brands very high end components. There’s lots of RTX 3090’s out there, but the best of the best are ones like the Galax HOF or Colorful Kudan 3090’s which absolutely curb stomp everyone else.
But those parts of that caliber are ludicrously expensive, that’s where you’re paying for much more than just the core die of the gpu or the chipset of the motherboard, you’re paying for extra features, materials, aesthetic design, and those attributes aren’t viewed the same by the average system builder. If you’re looking for the average metric of price to performance and want the quality and reputation you’ll usually end up somewhere in the middle. That middle is mostly the same across nearly all manufacturers, the step before the enthusiast tier option.

Lunar New Year Edition

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>>91045275
>Also, how fucking retarded is the install media?
You want me to explain how the boot process works? Alright, I'll explain to you how the boot process works.

After the Power-On-Self-Test (POST) the CPU starts executing whatever the BIOS feeds it. At this point the CPU is in so-called Real Mode, which is some arcane 80s mumbo jumbo that only has one 1 megabyte of address space to work with, which is not equivalent to 1 megabyte of RAM - there's all sorts of other shit mapped into that megabyte, like video RAM, the BIOS code itself, some registers, the works, and traditionally only the lower 640 KB were actually mapped to RAM ("640 KB ought to be enough for everybody" said literally no one ever).

Real Mode has a couple of advantages that no one cares about these days, like that I/O (hard disks, solid disks, flash memory, etc.) is being taken care of by the BIOS, via BIOS interrupts; there is no need to load in any I/O drivers. Since
1 megabyte obviously isn't enough for anything these days any reasonable kernel out there tries to switch to Protected (32-bit) or Long (64-bit) as quickly as possible; however, once the switch happened, the BIOS is officially out of the equation (unless you switch back to virtual real mode, which is real slow and real bothersome, but used to be the fallback on older DOS-based Windows' like 95 or 98 in case the IDE driver couldn't be loaded), so the system already needs to have its I/O drivers loaded into memory in case it needs to load in more stuff from some drives.

What happens with Windows 7 is that the CPU is in Real Mode, during which it loads in the kernel and its drivers and all that fun stuff, and then switches modes to Protected/Long Mode. There it realizes that it has no USB 3.0 drivers and cannot continue the install process.
>t. nigger

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91045574
In a way: yes. On the other hand Windows has no issues using more than 1 megabyte of address space, so I'd call them tied for stupidity.

The 1 megabyte limit stems from the fact that Intel was a bunch of lazy faggots and didn't want to put bigger registers on their processors, so they would use two smaller 16-bit ones to calculate 20-bit addresses (yes, 20 bit, not 32, which is about the equivalent of one megabyte vs. 4 gigabyte). This design decision would give rise to a branch of jobs whose only technical expertise needed to be to know in which order to load drivers on DOS so that as much contiguous conventional memory (the 640 KB chunk) was available. The best thing, however, is that emulators like DOSBox don't have all that many drivers in conventional memory to begin with, and thus have sometimes too LITTLE memory usage. It's why people sometimes have to use shit like loadfix to make sure enough conventional memory is being used so that the program isn't loaded into a chunk where it manages to fuck itself broken.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91045692
Nah, LOADFIX was in real DOS too. It was born, as you touch on, to deal with large amounts of conventional memory being available. In The Beginning(TM), DOS (being the first "program") loaded in the first 64KB of conventional memory, so no application could ever allocate memory in the first 64KB. A lot of language runtime libraries therefore walled off the first 64KB from their malloc() implementations for things like NULL pointer detection (something Windows still does - try to VirtualAllocEx() with a base below 64KB, and it'll tell you to fuck off).

Then along came 286s, with their flashy 24 bit address bus and "Extended Memory" shit, and due to a quirk of how x86 does real-mode addressing, suddenly there was about 64KB of RAM available on the 1MB line (whole cute story behind that, thus birthing the A20 gate), which was dubbed the "high memory area". To maximise conventional RAM, DOS offered the option to load itself high (hence DOS=HIGH in many CONFIG.SYSs of the time). Problem was, now that the first 64KB of RAM was free, programs can (and often did) get memory addresses below the 64KB line, fucking them right up.

And this is what LOADFIX did: simply forced the program to load at, or above, the 64KB line.

Thus endeth the history lesson. Please dislike and diatribe, and berate me on Hatreon.

posts.sub: /iemg/ & /pmpg/ - In-Ear Monitor & Portable Music Player General
posts.com:
Asano Tanch edition

How to request advice:
>Budget
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Intended use
>Sound signature (or genres you like)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them

FAQs:
>Do I need a DAC/dongle?
Only if your source: lacks a headphone jack, has high noise/distortion (common on PC), or lacks power, i.e. your IEMs don't get loud enough
>Should I buy FiiO/CCA/KZ?
No. Despite their previous popularity, in 2023 these companies do not make competitive IEMs or DACs
>Where do I buy IEMs?
Amazon, Aliexpress, Linsoul, HiFiGo, Shenzenaudio

Guide to IEMs:
https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu

Showerhead earbuds that don't insert in ear canal:
• Vido / KBEAR Stellar (bassy neutral) - ~$5
• RY4S 32Ω mmcx Plus (V-shape) - $10
• VE Monk Plus (bright neutral) bundle w/ Abigail dongle - $15

Bullet IEMs that are worn wire-down:
• Moondrop Quarks DSP (Harman) *USB-C DAC has noise/hiss! - $15
• Final E500 (dark neutral) - $25
• Tanchjim Tanya (bassy neutral) - $25
• Etymotic ER2XR (bassy neutral) *deep insert! - $100

#Budget IEMs that are worn wire-over-ear with detachable cable:
• 7Hz Salnotes Zero (bright neutral) - $20
• QKZ x HBB (very bassy) - $20
• Tangzu Wan'er S.G (mild V) - $20
• Truthear Hola (bassy neutral) - $20

#Sweetspot IEMs with better build, accessories, and sound:
• Tinhifi C2 (bright neutral) - $30
• Tinhifi C3 (Harman) - $50
• TKZK Ouranos (mild U) - $55
• Moondrop Aria Snow Edition (warm neutral) - $80
• Tripowin x HBB Olina SE (bright neutral) - $100

#MidFi IEMs that are 1DD:
• Tanchjim New Hana 2021 (mild V) - $180
• Moondrop KATO (warm neutral) - $190
• Thieaudio Elixir (bassy neutral) - $210

#MidFi IEMs that are not 1DD:
• Tangzu Zetian Wu (V-shape) - $150
• Letshuoer S12 Pro (bassy V) - $170
• SeeAudio Yume II (Harman) - $200

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
so i got my wan'er
this thing is actually really damn good for the price. i like it way more than the qkz x hbb, but things aren't adding up... the wan'er has a way higher midbass response than the graphs seem to indicate, it actually sounds pretty close to my ikko oh10 in the bass and low mids (obvs the oh10 is still way better and has a delicious rumble, and the highs are way richer in the oh10, the wan'er sounds thin and synthetic by comparison, with hi-hats being weak and splashy yet overly prominent)
the qkz x hbb has a way thumpier midbass but the sub-bass is kind of lacking, there's not rumble so much as bam and the inverse is true for the wan'er. Could unit variance really explain such pronounced difference and seeming deviation from the graphs on crin and squiglink?

Other than that though I'll review the wan'er I received. The stock cable and tips are among the best I've encountered across all the price ranges. The shells are pretty for what they are, although the center gold emblem on both of mine is sort of cloudy, looks like dried cum over the plastic desu while the smaller emblem on the bottom of the earpieces is clear shiny gold. They are comfortable, isolation is adequate, they're really light and fit snugly enough that I'd say these are perfect "athletic" IEMs if you do a lot of cardio or sports. Sound as I've mentioned, surprisingly warm, pleasant in the lower frequencies, but not quite to the point of being rumbly so bassheads still will need to look elsewhere, although I would probably steer bassheads on a budget toward the wan'er over the qkz x hbb unless you listen to rap. Upper frequencies will probably need some EQ to make vocals sound their best and tame the hi-hats and cymbals. Oh and the cloth is really low res and mine came with the corner unraveling, the boxart is way higher res so if you like that geisha lady just look for a print shop oo something on ali and pay a little extra to get that design

>>91030894
learn how a balanced connection works to answer your question

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91030894
If you're constantly going back and forth between different sources, some balanced and some single ended, or if you're mostly using one balanced source but need to use a single ended one every now and then, then yes, you can use a balanced cable and 3.5 male to 4.4/2.5 female adapter that turns your balanced cable into a single ended one.
If ipod is your only source (or if all your sources are single ended) then it doesn't make any sense, just use a single ended cable.
Be extra wary of shit like 3.5 female to 2.5/4.4 male. Shorting two outputs together creates a short circuit, it can destroy your amp.

>>91043614
\a is the BEL character, it makes your terminal emulator make noise. It's annoying as shit and everyone who uses it should be lynched. \033[ is how ansi escape sequences start, you can also use \e[. In this case they're both for color. 38;2;255;0;0 is literally just 255/0/0 in RGB. m closes the sequence. 0;38m is not actually a valid sequence but 30-37 are (for cterm colors 0-7) so he's presumably relying on the terminal emulator to take the opportunity to reset back to its default color. I dunno how many will actually work like that but Konsole does. You should note that only 8-color palettes are actually part of the spec, people get to 16 by assuming that "intense" text is the brighter half of the 16-color palette. 256 and truecolor are just completely fucking made up but they're widely supported enough that it's not normally a problem. You can read more on ye olde https://wikiless.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

typedef struct node {
    char* data;
    struct node* next;
    struct node* prev;
} node;

node* create_node(char* data) {
    node* new_node = (node*) malloc(sizeof(node));
    new_node->data = (char*) malloc(sizeof(char) * (strlen(data) + 1));
    strcpy(new_node->data, data);
    new_node->next = NULL;
    new_node->prev = NULL;
    return new_node;
}

void insert_at_beginning(node** head, char* data) {
    node* new_node = create_node(data);
    if (*head == NULL) {
        *head = new_node;
        return;
    }
    (*head)->prev = new_node;
    new_node->next = *head;
    *head = new_node;
}

void insert_at_end(node* head, char* data) {
    node* new_node = create_node(data);
    node* current = head;
    while (current->next != NULL) {
        current = current->next;
    }
    current->next = new_node;
    new_node->prev = current;
}

void insert_at_index(node** head, char* data, int index) {
    if (*head == NULL) {
        *head = create_node(data);
        return;
    }
    if (index == 0) {
        insert_at_beginning(head, data);
        return;
    }
    node* current = *head;
    int i;
    for (i = 0; i < index - 1; i++) {
        if (current->next == NULL) {
            break;
        }
        current = current->next;
    }
    node* new_node = create_node(data);
    new_node->prev = current;
    new_node->next = current->next;
    if (current->next != NULL) {
        current->next->prev = new_node;
    }
    current->next = new_node;
}

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <complex.h>

typedef int (*compare_func)(const void*, const void*);

int compare_complex(const void* a, const void* b) {
    double complex x = *(double complex*)a;
    double complex y = *(double complex*)b;
    if(creal(x) != creal(y)) return (creal(x) < creal(y)) ? -1 : 1;
    else return (cimag(x) < cimag(y)) ? -1 : 1;
}

void rotate(double complex* arr, unsigned int len, unsigned int k) {
    double complex* temp = (double complex*)malloc(k*sizeof(double complex));
    unsigned int i;
    for(i = 0; i < k; i++) temp[i] = arr[i];
    for(i = 0; i < len-k; i++) arr[i] = arr[i+k];
    for(i = 0; i < k; i++) arr[i+len-k] = temp[i];
    free(temp);
}

int main() {
    double complex arr[] = {1.0 + 2.0*I, 3.0 + 4.0*I, 2.0 + 3.0*I, 5.0 + 7.0*I, 6.0 + 8.0*I};
    unsigned int len = sizeof(arr)/sizeof(arr[0]);

    qsort(arr, len, sizeof(double complex), (compare_func)compare_complex);
    rotate(arr, len, 2);

    for(unsigned int i = 0; i < len; i++)
        printf("%lf + %lfi\n", creal(arr[i]), cimag(arr[i]));

    return 0;
}

#include <stdio.h>

#include <string.h>
#include <setjmp.h>

typedef struct {
    int x, y;
} Point;

Point* create_point(int x, int y) {
    Point* p = (Point*)malloc(sizeof(Point));
    p->x = x;
    p->y = y;
    return p;
}

int compare_points(const void* a, const void* b) {
    Point* p1 = *(Point**)a;
    Point* p2 = *(Point**)b;
    if(p1->x != p2->x) return p1->x - p2->x;
    else return p1->y - p2->y;
}

void sort_points(Point** points, int len) {
    qsort(points, len, sizeof(Point*), compare_points);
}

jmp_buf buf;

void error_handler(const char* msg) {
    longjmp(buf, 1);
}

int main() {
    Point* points[5];
    points[0] = create_point(3, 4);
    points[1] = create_point(2, 3);
    points[2] = create_point(5, 7);
    points[3] = create_point(6, 8);
    points[4] = create_point(1, 2);

    if(setjmp(buf) == 0) {

        for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++)

}

extern signed long int read  (signed int,       void *, unsigned long int);
extern signed long int write (signed int, const void *, unsigned long int);

extern signed int open  (const char *, signed int);
extern signed int close (              signed int);

signed int main (argc, argv)
const signed int     argc;
const char       * * argv; {
    signed        int input  = - 1;
    signed        int output = - 1;
    signed   long int stop   = + 1;
             char     a      = '0';
             char     z      = '0';
    unsigned char     data   = (unsigned char) 0X00;

    if (argc != 3)
        return (0XA0);

    if ((input = open (* (argv + 1), 0)) == - 1)
        return (0XF2);

    if ((output = open (* (argv + 2), 1 | 64 | 512)) == - 1)
        return (0XF2);

    loop:

    data = (unsigned char) 0X00;

    read_upper_4_bits:

    if ((stop = read (input, & a, (unsigned long int) 1)) == - 1)
        return (0XF0);

    if (stop == (signed long int) 0)
        goto exit;

    if (a == ' ' || a == '	' || a == '
')
        goto read_upper_4_bits;

    if (a >= '0' && a <= '9')
        data = (unsigned char) ((unsigned int) (a - '0') << 4);
    else if (a >= 'A' && a <= 'F')
        data = (unsigned char) ((unsigned int) (a - 'A' + '
') << 4);
    else
        return (0XEE);

    read_lower_4_bits:

    if ((stop = read (input, & z, (unsigned long int) 1)) == - 1)
        return (0XF0);

    if (stop == (signed long int) 0)
        goto exit;

    if (z == ' ' || z == '	' || z == '
')
        goto read_lower_4_bits;

    if (z >= '0' && z <= '9')
        data |= (unsigned char) (z - '0');
    else if (z >= 'A' && z <= 'F')
        data |= (unsigned char) (z - 'A' + '
');
    else
        return (0XEE);

    (void) write (output, & data, (unsigned long int) 1);

    if (stop > (signed long int) 0)
        goto loop;

    exit:

    if (close (input) != 0)
        return (0XF3);

    if (close (output) != 0)
        return (0XF3);

    return (0X3C);
}

>>91032891
C has always been notoriously shit for writing HPC. Which is why HPC writers have historically always turned to Fortran and later Sepples.
The absence of a good array data structure (VLAs are shit) makes it hard to generate performant assembly code.
To write a C code that will use all the parallelization and vectorization that a naive Fortran code would, you need to fill your code with a bunch of restrict keywords, #pragma must_iterate and other arcane instructions because C sucks at specifying intention.
No immutable data structure.
Shoddy atomic support.
The only way to do polymorphism in C is tocast everything to void pointer, which means bye bye static analysis and bye bye many vector optimisations (typed language btw).
No real bit cast. Pointer reinterpretation will lead to different on different machines.
The lack of structural matching leads most programmers to do design by side effect, which sucks for parallel computing.
No reference counting obviously.
The lack of all the things mentioned leads programmers to take the easy way out and put mutexes everywhere.
The alternative is to implement a whole infrastructure of job queues and software caches yourself, resulting in tens of thousands of additional LoCs and a hard to maintain codebase.
Fizzbuzzers will drop some "get good" bullshit because they think their tiny personal project counts as professional qualification. Writing for a C project like that involves having an entire picture of the machines state in your mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>https://project-mage.org/the-power-of-structure#Fern
Are the "schema" things meant to be like an OOP system where the class is equal to the instance?
It seems kind of interesting. I wonder if you could implement it using MOP to gain some benefits like type checks and other nice things.
Constraints appear to be roughly equivalent to a lambda which takes the scheme it is in as an implicit argument; though the fact that they can be circular appears odd - I'm not sure how exactly to model that. In general, constraints remind me of a thing I saw in GOOPS years ago, which is slots with :virtual allocation - they were essentially functions that took the object they were in as an argument and returned their value. It was quite an elegant system - it seems somewhat simpler than the constraint system, but not as powerful.

Looking at the code for kr, there seems to be some room for improvement. E.g. the is-* functions in kr-macros.lisp look up a dynamic variable (*is-*-bit*) which seems both weird (are the bits expected to change over time?) and inefficient. In general, it seems like the code uses a LOT of dynamic variables, which may be problematic with multithreading - which is probably necessary for a GUI toolkit. It's not high priority but it should be done at some point. I'd use some libraries such as serapeum and alexandria to make it a bit cleaner.

(define (circle-xy-generator r x0 y0 step)
  ;; [circle-xy-generator r x0 y0 step] returns a list of numerical tuples describing a
  ;; circle of radius [r] centered at [x0] [y0], [step] degrees apart (in degrees, not rad)
  (define (circle-function r x0 y0)
    (lambda (t) (list (+
               (* r (cos (degree->rad t)))
               x0)
              (+ (* r (sin (degree->rad t)))
             y0))))
  (let ((t (seq 0 360 step))
    (circle (circle-function r x0 y0)))
    (map circle t)))

(define (3-circles r x0 y0)
  (append (circle-xy-generator r x0 y0 1)
      (circle-xy-generator r (+ (* 2 r) x0) y0 1)
      (circle-xy-generator r (+ r x0) (+ (*  2 r (sin (/ pi 3))) y0) 1)))

In theory you can build an entire multiprocessing system out of nothing but call/cc. In practice it's too slow to use. One of those "elegant but not practical" aspects of scheme. COULD it be implemented in a fast practical way? A good project for a thesis paper maybe.

>>91018392
It depends.
The best functionality of guix home is actually managing services, although you have to write them yourself right now.
Dotfiles/configs - it's kind of meh.
Packages, I manage most packages in profiles other than the guix home profile. But this service does make it work better: 
(define (profilize-files list-of-profiles)
  "Converts a list of profiles into a text file appended to ~/.profile"
  (list (plain-file "profiles"
                    (fold
                     (lambda (profile str)
                       (string-append
                        str
                        "GUIX_PROFILE=" (getenv "HOME") "/" profile "\n"
                        ". " (getenv "HOME") "/"
                        profile "/etc/profile" "\n"))
                     ""
                     list-of-profiles))))

(define additional-profiles-service-type
  (service-type (name 'additional-profile)
                (extensions
                 (list (service-extension home-shell-profile-service-type
                                          profilize-files)))
                (default-value '())
                (description
                 "This service accepts a list of strings denoting profile filenames
relative from the home directory to be sourced.")))

I like these features of R5RS over R6RS:
> case insensitive
> character set agnostic
> smaller standard
In fact Sketchy Scheme is entirely R5RS because the author doesn't like how big R6RS is.
I like how R6RS doesn't require as many SRFIs to be useful, has better exception-handling constructs and less undefined behavior though.
Additionally, R7RS(smol) is mostly similar to R5RS and they both don't have syntax-case, which is a big dealbreaker for me; sure I can implement it myself, but that's besides the point.

>>91029529
Because they are read as literal by default, as per standard. Emacs will even highlight regex groups parenthesis provided you escape them properly.
https://www.gnu.org/software/sed/manual/html_node/BRE-syntax.html#BRE-syntax
And yes, it does work.
(let ((string "/this/is/a/test/"))
  (string-match "\\(.+?\\)/?$" string)
  (match-string 1 string))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91029725
You need to "double escape" because the string literal you write is first read by the Lisp reader, which applies its own escaping rules.
For example, if you try (read-string "\(.+?\)/?$") you'll see that nothing is actually escaped, because "\(" is not a special combination in Lisp and is thus translated to just "(". If you escape the backslash, the resulting string will contain a literal backslash, and so, when later read by the regex engine, will work as expected.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91031296
You could do it, but you'd be losing common ascii characters too. The issue is it'd be very easy o the language side but would require an entire pre-reader reader on the editor side, or worse some sort of markup script that got compiled into lisp.
You need to be able to override the main string reader, which has to work on unicode, and then integrate it with the editor to replace text as it's typed. Which essentially means the editor and language have to be the same and tightly integrated.
So elisp is maybe the only language currently in existence where you could do it, but it doesn't have reader macros. So I guess that means only LEM could pull it off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91033728
I'm gonna tell you the same thing I told the other anon (was it you?), macros make more sense when you arrive at them logically

imagine a lisp without macros. in this lisp, you could still use functions to generate lists that look exactly like lisp code, such as
> (list 'define 'my-add (list 'lambda (list 'x 'y) (list '+ 'x 'y))))
(define my-add (lambda (x y) (+ x y)))


and since lisp-without-macros still has eval, calling eval on the expression above would have the same effect as if I had written the expression in code:
> (eval (list 'define 'my-add (list 'lambda (list 'x 'y) (list '+ 'x 'y))))
> (my-add 420 69)
489

my-add wasn't "really" a function, it was just a normal list, but since it looks like a function, it can be evaluated as a function and used as a function.

macros are just a formalization of this idea. they're a natural consequence of how lisp works. a macro is a function that generates a list that can be evaluated as lisp code (and other things, but leave this for later), and macros are expanded before the code itself is read by the lisp system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91034093
Out of the box, you have open-line (bound to C-o by default), which opens a new line above the current cursor position, but it is different from Vim's "o" and "O" since it splits the current line instead of always inserting a new empty line regardless of position.

There are many ways to implement functions that work similarly to Vim's commands, the following is a possible example:

(defun anon-open-line ()
  (interactive)
  (move-beginning-of-line nil)
  (open-line 1))

(defun anon-newline ()
  (interactive)
  (move-end-of-line nil)
  (newline 1 nil))


You can then bind these functions to any key combination you want.

Alternatively, if you use evil-mode, just do what >>91034129 said.

posts.com:
An implementation of Damm algorithm https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damm_algorithm
(defconst table '((0 3 1 7 5 9 8 6 4 2)
                  (7 0 9 2 1 5 4 8 6 3)
                  (4 2 0 6 8 7 1 3 5 9)
                  (1 7 5 0 9 8 3 4 2 6)
                  (6 1 2 3 0 4 5 9 7 8)
                  (3 6 7 4 2 0 9 5 8 1)
                  (5 8 6 9 7 2 0 1 3 4)
                  (8 9 4 5 3 6 2 0 1 7)
                  (9 4 3 8 6 1 7 2 0 5)
                  (2 5 8 1 4 3 6 7 9 0)))

(defun number->list (num)
  (string-to-list (mapcar (lambda (x) (- x 48)) (number-to-string num))))

(defun lookup (target index)
  (nth target (nth index table)))

(defun keep-looking-up (list-of-numbers interrim-digit)
  (cond
   ((null interrim-digit)
    (keep-looking-up list-of-numbers 0))
   ((= (length list-of-numbers) 1)
    (lookup (car list-of-numbers) interrim-digit))
   (t
    (keep-looking-up (cdr list-of-numbers) (lookup (car list-of-numbers) interrim-digit)))))

(defun damm-give (number)
  "Given a number NUMBER, return a number with its check digit appended."
  (let* ((number-list (number->list number))
         (check-digit (keep-looking-up number-list nil)))
    (string-to-number (concat (mapcar (lambda (x) (+ x 48)) (append number-list (list check-digit)))))))

(defun damm-verify (number)
  "Verify the number NUMBER with is a number with its check digit apped end."
  (let* ((number-list (number->list number))
         (check-digit (keep-looking-up number-list nil)))
    (zerop check-digit)))

There is a lot of advice in your statement and it may be overwhelming to try and do everything at once. It is important to focus on a few key areas at a time and build upon them. Building projects outside of school/work, expanding your network, and creating a website/portfolio to showcase your experience can all be great ways to gain experience and make yourself stand out. Additionally, learning multiple programming languages and taking classes with large projects can also be beneficial. It is also important to practice algorithms and data structures, and to continually work on improving your skills in these areas. It's also important to understand the basics of big O notation as well as mastering data structures and algorithms. It may be helpful to start with a specific programming language and then branch out to others. While it's great to have a lot of knowledge in different areas, it's important to not bite off more than you can chew, and you may want to focus on one or two areas and then expand to others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91044692
The idea that life is unfair to everyone can be interpreted in different ways, but in general, it suggests that life is not equitable or just for everyone. However, the idea that if life is unfair to everyone, it is fair is a bit of a paradox.

In some ways, it could be argued that since everyone experiences difficulties and challenges in life, the fairness or unfairness of life is relative and subjective. However, in other ways, it could be argued that if everyone is experiencing unfairness, then the system is fundamentally flawed.

It's also important to remember that unfairness can take many forms and can be caused by a variety of factors such as systemic discrimination, lack of access to resources, and privilege. When these issues aren't addressed, they can perpetuate a cycle of unfairness that affects certain groups of people more than others.

It's important to remember that fairness and justice are not the same thing. Justice refers to the fair and impartial treatment of all individuals under the law. Fairness, on the other hand, can refer to the distribution of resources, opportunities, and privileges in society. Achieving fairness and justice require active efforts, rather than assuming they occur automatically.

>>91046987
>I need to think a little more than im comfy with i stop, dont want to anymore, i get scared into hell circles of
This is matter of work hygiene. Your brain rewards you for learning new things, but the low hanging fruits run out quickly and than you have to put in some effort to keep going. That's why it's important to work on your own schedule and plan out adequately sized future steps, so you can ignore other cravings and focus on what you've planned to do. As soon as you develop habits to learn/practice it becomes easy.

>perhaps im just telling me that cuz im scared, just continue working, what if I dont like it? what if I just tell me this because im scared and I actually like it?
Your brain is more malleable than you think. Once you start to get some real returns you will like it. And even if you don't like specific area, programming skills transcendent languages and frameworks and it's very easy to just change. You might even move to math or other related disciplines.

>What can i do against that? How do i know that programming or SOMETHIGN is my passion?
What becomes your passion is the result of your effort and dedication, not something hidden that will just magically make it easy to pursue something.

>Not only that but im never outside, dont have friends, depression, dont sleep, eat unhealthy and more that makes my life just shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91040014
No, you're an idiot. NoSQL was introduced at first to work with semi-structured data with differing number of columns per row per table and varying datatypes for a given column.

NoSQL doesn't mean it's not relational. It means it's not just relational. You can establish relations between tables in many NoSQL tables and you often do if a given table stores a limited amount of data that will be needed and used in each one of your partitions (like a categories table which would be replicated accross all your nodes).

NoSQL is also much better at horizontal scalability even though MySQL tries to keep up with Cassandra & Mongo by swapping their engine with RocksDB and Postgres with extensions such as Citus. It's still a pain in the ass to setup sharding and replication. Now a solution to that (that makes sharding easier at scale) is to split your db into databases with a bounded context first (basically microservices). Since the relationships are limited to a small number of entities which are part of a bounded context the sharding is much easier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whether you use SQL or NoSQL, eventually you should use an architecture that uses caching to satisfy most of your reads, and use a queue to batch up most of your writes. Or use multiple database instances to spread out the load.

The thing is that NoSQL makes partitioning your database into multiple instances easier than regular SQL unless you split your application into microservices at which point each service would own its own schema which represents a bounded context which can be partitioned much more easily.

>>91043327
I didn't say anything that contradicts your statement. I even specified what these usecases are.

>>91043562
If you design your bounded contexts correctly, you won't need to do 3 network calls most of the time. Let's take your example. Your customer is most likely already authenticated so he already has his information in the client and the parts that should not be shown (say his Id) are part of the claims of his httpOnly JWT (which he sends back to your api as part of the headers of the request). The existence of a bounded context also involves that some referencial data belonging to a given context and needed elsewhere should be replicated where it will be often needed. So the application server will only make a call to a single database server (either the orders or the shipping server depending on how you designed your app). If your microservices rely on cross boundary calls for a lot of requests, then you're not really building microservices.

Also, you don't need microservices unless you're a relatively large team, you are right. You don't need domain driven design either if your backend is simple, but you will need it if your codebase is large and needs to frequently change over time.

If you have a lot of business rules and a lof of features, you can still build a monolith with bounded context and DDD that would make testing, refactoring, maintainability easier. I've seen too many projects that didn't abide by this rule evolve into a messy ball of mud where the devs were too afraid to touch the code out of fear of breaking anything. Everything has a purpose and a context where its justified. It may not be justified for what you're building.

DDD/Clean architecture allows you to decouple your infrastructure/persistence layer from your application and your presentation layer. When implemented correctly, you can swap your database, email provider or your communication protocol (rest, websocket, graphql, grpc) without refactoring your app/domain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91049070
In addition to ddd/clean architecture, you can use vertical slices to divide your codebase into exportable feature modules that you can inject to any other project you want with near 0 refactoring. You won't need any of these for a simple but if you're starting a company or projecting yourself in the future you want your code to be easily testable, your dependencies to be easily replaceable without having to refactor anything on the application layer, your features to be decoupled from each other to allow refactoring of a feature without breaking the code you wrote elsewhere or to export these features to another project if you need them instead of rewriting the same module (because it's tightly coupled).

Also, when it comes to sql databases, you can't keep vertically scaling your hardware for your single DB endlessly and the performance gain from doubling your specs doesn't produce the same output as creating another instance with the same specs. So at some point you want to scale horizontally and NO, relying on replication of your entire data doesn't scale and is a recipe for a disaster. Even postgres has a limit for the amount of data it can store before the performance starts to degrade. Bounded context allows you to postpone this concern and to make easier to partition your tables and use hashing keys to know to which node the request must be sent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
for best possible quality to filesize ratio use two-pass. it's also important to keep threads at 1 as multi-threaded encoding can produce artifacts

#! /bin/sh
ffmpeg -i $1 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -pass 1 -qmin 0 -qmax 50 -crf 10 -b:v 1M -threads 1 -tile-columns 0 -speed 4 -g 128 -aq-mode 0 -an -sn -f webm /dev/null

ffmpeg -i $1 -c:v libvpx-vp9 -pass 2 -qmin 0 -qmax 50 -crf 10 -b:v 1M -c:a libopus -b:a 64K -vbr on -threads 1 -tile-columns 0 -speed 0 -auto-alt-ref 1 -lag-in-frames 25 -g 128 -aq-mode 0 -sn -f webm output.webm

Im pretty sure that's not entirely true. If you set a static bitrate, it can use that and come to the filesize everytime.

its only using quality settings like qp and crf that it cannot know exactly because the bitrate is entirely variable and based on a an idea of quality. But you can still set limits to them and you either get a file that's smaller (the bitrate you set was generous for the quality), a file size that's the same (you set the right bitrate to match the quality) or a filesize that is also the same but worse (the quality was set too high and required more bitrate than you set at all times so it becamse constant bitrate again).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048249
calculate a bitrate and tell it to use that (highly recommend you use 2-pass in this case, single-pass fixed-bitrate is only suitable for fixed-bandwidth applications such as radio transmission)

for example say you have a 1:45 video and want it to be about 4MB, you want to divide the size by the length, to get the amount of data per unit of time you can use, for example,
(4*1024*8*1000)/(1*60+45)

will give you the bits-per-second you can use as a bitrate argument to ffmpeg, that's
4*1024 = size in KiB
*8 = size in Kib
*1000 = size in b
and
1*60 = minutes in seconds
+45 = plus the seconds

the difference between 1 and 2 pass is that with 1 pass, the bitrate will be the same the whole way through the video, as ffmpeg can't know where best to use the bits before it encodes the video, while for 2 pass, the first pass analyzes the video, giving ffmpeg the information it needs on the second pass to distribute the available bits more intelligently, that is, using more bits during complex scenes, and less bits in still scenes, increasing the quality overall

clip related, using that formula putting in 6 seconds and 200KiB target, the resulting clip is a little bigger as this does not include container overhead and it's also just not exact, so undershoot the size a bit if it must be under a certain size
ffmpeg -i INTENSIFIES.webm -map 0:v -c:v libvpx-vp9 -b "(0.2*1024*8*1000)/(0*60+6)" -pass 1 -y out.webm
ffmpeg -i INTENSIFIES.webm -map 0:v -c:v libvpx-vp9 -b "(0.2*1024*8*1000)/(0*60+6)" -pass 2 -y out.webm

>>91048691
ffmpeg guesses the output format based on the filename extension you use (for example it assumes "-f webm" if you use "somename.webm")
with NUL as the filename, it can't tell what format you want it to output in, so you need to specify it manually, "-f matroska" and "-f nut" should work for just about any streams

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048691
-map 0:v -an

this is redundant, -an excludes audio streams, while my -map 0:v instead includes video streams from the first input (and it's explicit, meaning any other kinds of streams are implicitly excluded)
this is more reliable as it will also exclude things like subtitles which you also can't post here
you can be more specific with -map 0:v:0 (first video stream of first file), but this is only needed if the input has more than one video stream, which is so rare i usually don't bother adding it

also, I wonder if there is a better way to do this
import React from 'react'
import UserName from './components/userName.js'
import UserPassword from './components/userPassword.js'


export default class Register extends React.Component {
  constructor(props){
    super(props)
    this.state = {userName: '', userPassword: ''};
    this.style = {userName: '', userPassword: ''}
    this.onUserNameChange = this.handleUserNameChange.bind(this);
    this.onUserPasswordChange = this.handlePasswordChange.bind(this);

  }
  handleUserNameChange(event){
    const value = event.target.value;
    this.setState( { userName: value } )
    if (value.length > 4){
      this.style.userName = "validText";
    } else {
      this.style.userName = "invalidText";
    }
  }
  handlePasswordChange(event){
    const value = event.target.value;
    this.setState( { userPassword: value } )
    if (value.length > 4){
      this.style.userPassword = "validText";
    } else {
      this.style.userPassword = "invalidText";
    }
  }

  render(){
    console.log(this)
    return <form>
      <label for="registerUserName">Username</label><UserName register={this}/>
      <label for="registerPassword">Password</label><UserPassword register={this}/>
    </form>

  }
}

so that I wouldn't have to repurpose code for username and userpassword

Fargate is "serverless", it takes your containers and automatically handles provisioning for them based on demand. Auto Scaling still requires you to make a scaling plan and it provisions additional instances based on the plan and demand.
The even shorter version is that Fargate is hands-off, while Auto Scaling still requires some hands-on work for infra.

>>91048724
Yeah Laravel is fine. Postgres is excellent. Ultimately, it will depend on what you are trying to build. Here's a guideline:
>is your backend monolithic or distributed as microservices
>is your backend mostly i/o reliant or does it rely heavily on computation
> is your backend mostly transactional crud or is it analytical
> is your data structured or unstructured (semi-structured)
> do you have a feature that requires very high performance, low latency and high performance computing
>is your backend decoupled from your frontend or are they one single block (mvc)
>what kind of protocol do you use for communication (rest, graphql, grpc, websockets)
>what level of concurrency do you need and will your app run on commodity servers

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048724
>is your backend complex with a lot of features and business rules or is it simple
>what kind of libraries/dependencies of you need to rely only

See below. I'm filling a buffer with random data using the wyrand random number generator. The goofy behavior disappears at higher -O levels.
void fill_map_wyrand_new(char *buf, size_t length) {
    uint64_t *dst = (uint64_t *)buf;
    uint64_t seed = 0;
    register uint64_t s;
    
    getrandom(&seed, sizeof(seed), GRND_RANDOM);
    s = seed;
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < length / sizeof(uint64_t); i++) {
        s += UINT64_C(0xa0761d6478bd642f);
        __uint128_t t = (__uint128_t)s * (s ^ UINT64_C(0xe7037ed1a0b428db));
        dst[i] = (t >> 64) ^ t;
    }
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91043638
>>91044827

The code begins by setting up the stack frame for a function call.
The first instruction pushes 0x50 onto the stack, which is where the return address will be stored when this function returns.
Next, it sets up registers to hold values that are needed in order to make calculations later on.
It then calculates and stores into register %rax -0x48(%rbp), which is used as an index into a table of pointers to functions that need to be called during runtime.
The next two instructions calculate and store into register %rdx -0x50(%rbp) and %rax -0x48(%rbp).
These registers are used as indexes into tables of data that needs to be passed around during runtime.
The code attempts to take the value of %rax and store it in %rdx.
The code is also supposed to take the value of %rdx and store it in %rax.
The purpose of the code above is that both values are stored into their respective registers, but not before they are first moved from their current locations in memory (0x50(%rbp) and 0x48(%rbp)) to their new locations (0x48(%rbp) and 0x50(%rbp)).

How much of this is bullshit?

posts.com:
I'm not a programmer. I made this in batch that deletes files and renames old files back to the original name. In this case for a game mod. Because what I'm doing is in Program Files, Windows requires the .bat to be run as Admin. I have 2 problems.
1. The user may run the script and it appears to run, but doesn't because it wasn't run as Admin. I do include in my readme to run as admin.
2. Because my mods use the name of the existing files, on the drag and drop file install, I include the vanilla game files. The script deletes the mod file and renames the old file from the vanilla install back to it's original name which the modded file was using. If the user runs the uninstaller without my modpack installed, it will uninstall files from the base game with no replacement files to rename, breaking the game. The fix if a user does this is to restore the game back to vanilla is to reinstall the the mod and run the uninstaller only once this time. However, I am trying to implement some checking to prevent the user from being able to do this mistake in the first place.

@echo off
echo wscript.quit MsgBox ("Are you sure you want to uninstall?", 4, "Uninstall") > yesno.vbs
wscript //nologo yesno.vbs
set value=%errorlevel%
del yesno.vbs
if "%value%"=="7" exit /b

if "%value%"=="6" echo Uninstalling.
cd "C:\Program Files\Company\Game\RESOURCE\TEXTURES"
del "texture1.tf"
rename "texture1.old" "texture1.tf"
del "texture2.tf"

sub g {
    my ($array, $n) = @_;
    return [[]] if $n == 0;
    my @combinations;
    for my $i (0..$#{$array}) {
        my $elem = $array->[$i];
        for my $c (generate_combinations([@$array[0..$i-1, $i+1..$#{$array}]], $n-1)) {
            push @combinations, [$elem, @$c];
        }
    }
    return \@combinations;
}

my @array = (1..100);
my $n = scalar @array;
my $combinations = g(\@array, $n);

print scalar @$combinations;

#include <memory>
struct Foo {
    virtual const char* GetName() = 0;
    virtual int GetID() = 0;
    virtual ~Foo() = default;
};
#define FOO_MEMBER_MACRO            \
    const char* GetName() override; \
    int GetID() override;

struct Bar : Foo {
    FOO_MEMBER_MACRO
};
struct Baz : Foo {
    FOO_MEMBER_MACRO
};
struct Bat : Foo {
    FOO_MEMBER_MACRO
};

#define FOO_TYPE_MAP(XX) \
    XX(Bar, BAR)         \
    XX(Baz, BAZ)         \
    XX(Bat, BAT)

#define XX(_, id) FOO_##id,
enum { FOO_TYPE_MAP(XX) FOOTYPE_MAX };
#undef XX

#define XX(type, id)                            \
    const char* type::GetName() { return #id; } \
    int type::GetID() { return FOO_##id; }
FOO_TYPE_MAP(XX)
#undef XX

std::unique_ptr<Foo> CreateFoo(int id) {
#define XX(type, id)                     \
    case FOO_##id:                   \
        return std::make_unique<type>(); \
        break;
    switch (id) { FOO_TYPE_MAP(XX) }
#undef XX
    return std::unique_ptr<Foo>();
}

const char* FooID_to_Str(int id) {
#define XX(type, id)           \
    case FOO_##id:         \
        return #id; \
        break;
    switch (id) { FOO_TYPE_MAP(XX) }
#undef XX
    return "???";
}
#include <cstdio>
int main()
{
    Bar b;
    Baz z;
    Bat t;
    Foo *f = &b;
    printf("%s == %s
", f->GetName(), FooID_to_Str(FOO_BAR));
    f = &z;
    printf("%s == %s
", f->GetName(), FooID_to_Str(FOO_BAZ));
    f = &t;
    printf("%s == %s
", f->GetName(), FooID_to_Str(FOO_BAT));
}

#include <iostream>
#include <vector>

template <typename T>
class vec_ref {
public:
  vec_ref(std::vector<T>& vec_, int index_) : vec(vec_), index(index_) {}

  T get() {
    return vec[index];
  }

private:
  std::vector<T>& vec;
  int index;
};


int main(int argc, char** argv) {

  std::vector<int> vec;

  for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    vec.push_back(2*i);
  }

  vec_ref<int> ref(vec, 4);

  for (int i = 10; i < 20; i++) {
    vec.push_back(2*i);
  }

  std::cout << ref.get() << "\n";

  return 1;
}

def binary_to_decimal_converter(a):

printf is absolutely not a fucking system call. It is a C library function. System calls are functions provided by the operating system for interfacing with the kernel. The following is a table of every system call on Linux, alongside their system call number when used on x86_64 (the ordering of these may be different on other instruction sets):
https://filippo.io/linux-syscall-table/

On the same architecture, you will find the Windows system call table here:
https://j00ru.vexillium.org/syscalls/nt/64/

We can find the MacOS syscall table here:
https://opensource.apple.com/source/xnu/xnu-1504.3.12/bsd/kern/syscalls.master

None have printf. Why do you suppose that is?

>>91034177
Dunno about aerospace, I know they're more strict, but this guy claims he's using it in automotive.
I'm guessing the most important questions a spec answers are "is X allowed" and "does this code do X or Y". Rust already solves those issues well, at least in safe code. If the compiler accepts it it's allowed (modulo compiler bugs), and it's really rare for there to be two interpretations of a piece of code where both would actually compile, mainly because of how anal the static typing is. (The situation for unsafe code is not as good, they're still working on formalizing it, but there's decent tooling for verification and dynamic analysis.)
It does matter, and Ferrous Systems is working on a Rust spec for safety-critical applications. But I'm not sure it's a complete dealbreaker. Kind of talking out of my ass though, I don't do embedded.

>>91034257
>I don't know why nobody backing Rust (as in corps) care about this gigantic problem.
I don't think the software companies that back it suffer much from the problem, if at all. They're not deploying onto platforms that LLVM doesn't support, so alternative compilers don't matter to them, and it doesn't typically cause issues in day-to-day coding.
You might think it matters for backward compatibility but Rust solves that with brute force, by testing each release and risky change on half a million public codebases to see if anything breaks in practice.
GCC-rust targets rustc's test suite, which doesn't seem a terrible way to go about things.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91036597
>Read Usenet and you will see that the C community is saying the same thing now that they did 30 and 40 years ago.
Do you have a link to an example? Would make this a lot easier
>Possibly, but they make threads that are ONLY about calling Rust programmers "trannies" and not even one example of criticism of Rust.
Yeah, and there are people who make threads that are only about calling C users cniles. That's just the way this place is.
Probably more than half of anti-Rust posts contain good-faith arguments. (That's counting incorrect but earnest arguments.)
>No, safety is incredibly easy to understand. It just means your program won't access anything that isn't type safe like unallocated memory.
So easy that you got it wrong—accessing unallocated memory doesn't necessarily break type safety, since there are types that accept any bit pattern. It's unsafe because of compiler (and rarely allocator/kernel) optimizations that assume uninitialized memory won't be read.
But more importantly than that, safety is a broad concept that goes beyond the boundaries of Rust's unsafe keyword. Logic bugs can cause vulnerabilities too, even if Rust makes no guarantees in that department.
I like Rust but you're proving the guy you're arguing with right.

It can mean a couple things. It's a title for the current stage in history capitalism is in. Okay so here's my understanding of it.
Karl marx talked about something called the tendency of the rate of profit to fall. The way this works is that as productions methods become more efficient stuff becomes cheaper, but at the same time the worker must be squeezed more to keep up the profit. But the worker is also the consumer. These are the contradictions of capitalism. So he predicted that the rate of profit would keep falling as time goes on until it reaches 0 at which point capitalism would collapse followed by socialism and then communism.

>In December 1978, eighteen of the local farmers, led by Yen Jingchang,[5] met in the largest house in the village. They agreed to break the law at the time by signing a secret agreement to divide the land, a local People's Commune, into family plots. Each plot was to be worked by an individual family who would turn over some of what they grew to the government and the collective whilst at the same time agreeing that they could keep the surplus for themselves. The villagers also agreed that should one of them be caught and sentenced to death that the other villagers would raise their children until they were eighteen years old.[5][6] At the time, the villagers were worried that another famine might strike the village after a particularly bad harvest and more people might die of hunger.[6]

>After this secret capitalist reform, Xiaogang village produced a harvest that was larger than the previous five years combined.[5] Per capita income in the village increase from 22 yuan to 400 yuan with grain output increasing to 90,000 kg in 1979.[6] This attracted significant attention from surrounding villages and before long the government in Beijing had found out. The villagers were fortunate in that at the time China had just changed leadership after Mao Zedong had died. The new leadership under Deng Xiaoping was looking for ways to reform China's economy and the discovery of Xiaogang's innovation was held up as a model to other villages across the country. This led to the abandonment of collectivised farming across China and a large increase in agricultural production. The secret signing of the contract in Xiaogang is widely regarded as the beginning of the period of rapid economic growth and industrialisation that mainland China has experienced in the thirty years since.

From my understanding:
Capitalism: economic model based on capital: wealth come by owning stuff (having a second house you can rent, owning a store chain, getting patent right or copyright money...)
And anti-capitalism is the opposite of that: wealth comes from actual work and labour (produce value instead of exploiting what you already own).
So I think I'm anticapitalism but my definition of that is far from socialism or communism.

>>91029492
The average shower uses 2.5 gallons every minute, which is 150 gallons per shower. Let's say that anon is taking one every day - that's 4,500 gallons a month used. The average is 348 gallons. This isn't taking into account other utilities that require water, such as dishwasher and washing machine. With toilet, washing machine, faucet water, and dishwasher, the total now comes to about 5,850 gallons. This is far above the one person average of 2,460 gallons. The average bill is $41 for that 2,460 gallons, which comes to $0.016 (6 is repeating) per gallon, which means for 3,600 gallons the price is $97.50.

So yeah, maybe spending over double is undesirable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, the Linux app, or as I've recently taken to calling it, Linux is a macOS app.
Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free app in the Apple App Store and part of a fully functioning macOS system made useful by the Apple macOS, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the linux app every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of the linux app which is widely used today is often called "Linux", and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the macOS system, developed by Apple.

There really is a Linux, and there are people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the app: the program in the system that wastes the machine's resources to limit the other programs that you run. The app is an optional part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete macOS operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the macOS operating system: the whole system is basically macOS with Linux added, or Linux is a macOS app. All the so-called "Linux" apps are really flavors of linux apps on macOS.

>>91024692
>>91024940
I have one of those! I used it to teach myself to solder.

I do not recommend it unless you plan on taking it apart to put Millmax hotswap sockets into it, mainly to get rid of the shit-ass Cherry blues, and replacing the plate-mount stabilizers. Your assessment of it is correct, it has absolutely nothing interesting going on under the hood that you couldn't get out of a much, much cheaper keyboard. It's a very slick looking keyboard though and it's one of your two sources for good quality round "typewriter style" keycaps, the other source being Datamancer which will make them by hand out of metal, resin and plastic stems.

It's one of those things where it's not meant for you at all if you just want a mechanical keyboard, it's meant for people who want a mechanical keyboard that looks and feels like a typewriter and they'll pay extra to get it. Niche within a niche.

So after weighing my options for low profile mechanical keyboard with multiple connectivity options as a requirement I have decided the following
> MX Keys Mechanical Mini
Expensive, keycaps barely better than the other worse options, hard to find the right switches option
> Nuphy Air75
Actually looks decent, but the lack of 2.4ghz and the wonky travel case + feet put me off
> Keychron K3 Pro/K3v2
While having QMK/Via is nice, I've realised tools like KMonad exists and having this option is no longer that big of a pro. Also, no 2.4 ghz
> Azio Cascade Slim
Same tier with the Nuphy Air75, it was either this or the Nuphy but both lack 2.4ghz at same price point.

So I actually dug around AliExpress and decided to buy Chinese board with 2.4ghz, Bluetooth and Wired connection that comes with Hotswap and PBT keycap that is half the price of all the other options.

I use a multipen at work with 5 colors to keep track of work stuff in my day book. By default, every thing is in black. Meetings in purple, projects and keywords in green, people and annotations in blue, dates and decisions made in red. Kindof like syntax highlighting. It helps me skim based on whatever I'm looking for. I even write little table of contents on a per-month basis.
Specifically, the pen is a Coleto 5-Color Multi Pen. It's pretty cheap plastic though and I write like a neanderthal so they break in just over a year typically. The pen refills I use are called Hi-Tec-C, 0.4mm. They're overpriced imports from Japan, but great color and feel pretty good. I know there are better writing experiences out there, but this has proven the most handy for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91028423
I do it as a private hobby, no one knows i actually practice writing since i use a different style for day to day purposes. I've never thought of myself as being skilled enough to do commissions or sell my works, the lower end calligraphy market is over saturated with women who do whatever they want and it's pretty much impossible to get anywhere without joining a calligraphers guild/society for connections.
>there is no way I could justify to myself spending $500 on a pen
In this regard I lean on the collector side of the fence. So long as i have the disposable money i don't need any justification other then the fact that i want it and some other factors.
My most expensive pens which are over $500 i typically don't use (i can buy a user grade for half the price),
For daily use outside i use the cheaper and readily available stuff like my pilot VP.
Similarly for calligraphic work i use nibs are can be store bought, It's extraordinarily rare for me to touch my vintage collection.
It's a different mindset from buying a good tool knowing that it'll pay for it's self as a good investment for your work.
I always buy my pens and nibs knowing that they're not a good investment and that I'm losing money but I'm happy to have them because it's a hobby and i can afford it (If you buy pens as an investment i think you're genuinely retarded)
>Any work you want to show off
All the pictures in the wiki are mine, I guess i have some others lying around but i'm too lazy to take a photo. I'll just recycle one that i've taken before

posts.com: IceSword. It was a malware removal tool and general godmode for XP. Access denied reading a registry key? It parses the hive files itself. System won't let you delete a file? It modifies the filesystem structures on disk. Access denied terminating a process? It simply removes it from the run queue. Suspect a rootkit? It lets you see all files, registry keys, open ports, processes, etc. as read directly from disk or kernel memory instead of going through system calls that the rootkit might modify the result of.

every bbs who participated had a node number. your address was the node number, and your username. People still play everybody edits, even though the servers were taken offline in 2020. There is a small dedicated community who created an offline client, a TAS client, an archive of every world ever created, and modded clients with new blocks. Most of the discussion is around difficult worlds and pushing the game to its limit, but some people still make easy worlds.

I got BTFO'd for trying to use DRM to secure a P2P network.
The network desgin had "super peers" or Bailiffs that could kick other peers out, this creates an issue of fake bailiffs that would attempt a hostile takeover. But even worse every node had a cryptographic key that was vital to the network.

I've since removed the key and redesigned the network into a hybrid line bus.

New HYPR is an installation suite that distributes a program to (3) directories, it runs (3) associated processes and uses the admin's permission to restrict the folder to anyone but itself (yes this is a thing that happens). It runs on startup and has a taskbar launcher for executing the guarded program.

It can be circumvented by deleting it's autorun entries and opening it in an external drive.

Or deleting it's startup entry and restarting the computer.
Folder permissions can be changed from registries.

Old HYPR was over engineered and highly illegal.

The biggest problem isn't they is a statistical chance of a crash they are inherently unstable and are impossible to prove mathematically which means you can't be certain with any degree of confidence that a random challenge image won't cause a car to suddenly crash into a building. They are basically black box coding where you used training information in the hope it performs well but while you could possibly make it safer than any human all a bad actor needs to do is show a special picture in a random window and all self driving cars would crash into the other building because there was no way of ensuring all inputs will lead to valid outputs. In safety critical systems automation is good but you have to be able to prove it is statistically as safe as you say it is mathematically with failure models and predictive analysis. Deep learning models are inherently impossible to prove that even all normal inputs will result in stable output commands.

Let me tell you a story that will show itself to be pertinent to the situation.

An old (15+ years ago) Skype account of mine got hacked into. I couldn't recover the account, because I couldn't answer the arcane questions about what I did fifteen years ago (credit card numbers, contacts, last purchase amount, etc). The clearly fraudulent activity included using Skype Credit to purchase a Chinese phone card from a Chinese location. Well, I contact Microsoft IT and they ask me if I have recovered my account. No, I tell them. Then they say there's literally nothing I can do. The IT person suggests that I get people I know to report the account for suspicious activity. I tell them that there's no need, I am telling them about it right now with receipts. They say, again, there's nothing they can do about it.

I had to block the daily spam emails telling me there isn't enough money in the account to buy more Chinese call minutes. Meaning, the account has not been shut down 3 months after and probably never will be.

Now, imagine this situation after an automated system has essentially SWAT'd you. A warrant will be issued, a team of cops will kick in your door, shoot your dog, take all of your computers (and guns, and cash - civil forfeiture bitch), you will be held in jail, potentially go to trial. You'll have to call in to work and tell them you've been arrested but can't tell them for what, but that you are DEFINITELY innocent. Same with your family. Maybe the local newspaper writes about the local pedo that got raided.

The best outcome of this scenario, best possible case, is that an obese police officer tells you, "You are free to go," and they give you back some of the personal possessions they took, and perhaps they still work. And Apple will never have to deal with any of this. They just forward an alert to the cops over a scanned picture that matches a hash, meaning it potentially might be something that could be something else. But you will pay for it dearly.

Additionally, there may be other reasons for pursuing such a project, such as personal interest, passion, or a desire to contribute to the field. It is important to consider one's own goals, values, and interests when deciding whether or not to pursue a project.

>>91046352
I clicked through to https://skarnet.org/software/s6/socket-activation.html and https://forums.gentoo.org/viewtopic-t-994548-postdays-0-postorder-asc-start-25.html#7581522 and now I know that this dev doesn't understand how systemd works, but thinks he does and justifies his """better""" design with fake facts. Which is unfortunately par for the course for people who think Poettering pissed in their cereal.

>It requires a central registry of all the sockets you need, for all your services. Like a Microsoft Windows registry. It's a database of everything that's running on your system; this defeats the essence of modularity.
No, dumbass. Sockets are specified as .socket units just like services are specified as .service units.

>ways to open your sockets and bind them as early as you want in your boot process, and make them accept client connections later: s6-ipcserver-socketbinder, s6-tcpserver4-socketbinder and s6-tcpserver6-socketbinder.
Except these listen() on the socket themselves and then pass the connected socket down to the exec'd service, so the exec'd service can only act on one connection. Spawning a new process for every connection works for some use cases but not all. systemd gives you the choice to do one or the other.

ok
if you want to write a service that runs some command that will keep running until i send it the TERM signal, make a folder
inside that folder there will be 2 files
one file is named type and inside it is the word "longrun"
the other file is named run and it's a file with a shebang that will get executed when the service is run
here's the run file for a service i just wrote to start jackd
#!/bin/execlineb -P
export JACK_NO_AUDIO_RESERVATION 1
jackd -d alsa -o 2 -p 256

>>91032276
This has nothing to do with neuroplasticity. A dev is a commodity and if you're still coding after 30 your career is fucked.
I'm a wealthy dev, can code and read code but the only work that makes sense for me is to hire and manage devs. In fact this makes me super valuable because unlike hr retards I can see how competent someone actually is.

This isn't unique to coding. This is the fact of every industry. At some point you are supposed to amass enough wealth (some combination of financial and social capital) and the most valuable use of your time is to manage other people utilizing your past knowledge rather than doing stuff yourself. What separates those who make from those who don't is learning a new thing - the ability to delegate.
It was much less visible in the past because there was a massive shortage of devs. This massive shortage meant the relative value of management was much lower. That period is over. Being a dev doesn't require higher iq than being an engineer in many fields.

This is the transition period. In 10+ years western software devs will earn less than other engineers. Why? Because unlike eg. a process engineer working at a chemical company, it's much easier to outsource.
Instead of falling by the wayside you have to adapt - like starting a consulting company and directly hire foreign cheaper devs.

Note: the trick is to hire them directly. Many people go the retarded route and subcontract to some local company because they don't want to talk to Sasha or Pranav. This is a mental mistake in which all foreign devs are dehumanized as one big commodity pool you can tap into. No. What devs are going to work as dedicated offshoring companies? The worst ones, and if any good one ends up there as an accident, they leave immediately. The inevitable failure follows.

If you don't do this, chances are you will be fired as a dev at 40 and that's it.

Tor browser on Ubuntu only routes traffic through Tor if it's from the browser itself. Everything else goes through the clear net. Tails routes everything on the system through the Tor network. Whonix is set up in a similar way but takes advantage of VMs rather than Tails running in memory only.

posts.com:
I've been thinking a lot about the messaging around privacy these days... has anyone else noticed how it is represented in media?
What I mean is there are numerous examples of corporations co-opting the concept of privacy to promote their products, especially relying on fear as a marketing strategy.
"Buy our VPN service to protect yourself from harm!"
"Download our browser! You don't want certain people tracking your every move..."
"Use our app, not theirs! Trust us!"
"Buy our phone! It has privacy features to keep you safe"
etc.
This doesn't seem like a healthy direction for privacy. A fear campaign will only muddy the discussion around privacy and burn its goodwill. I definitely don't feel very trusting of a company that would claim that it is more trustworthy than another. It's doubly unfortunate that such companies seem to be controlling the narrative and promoting a fear campaign.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.
