posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91033537
>Do I have to now be the sysadmin for a publicly exposed server? Is it more or less secure than my ISP router?
Depends. Typically one would just expose a single port for wireguard to gain access to hosted services while out and about.
>Also os it better to put OPNsense on something like proxmox or just have it bare metal?
Although you technically could virtualize the firewall, it's best if you go the bare metal route. A good reason for doing so - rebooting the hypervisor (proxmox) would take down your network.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91034380
>but I might just buy a cheap CPU with one.
Ryzens consumer APUs are pretty bad, go for a low wattage setup.
>old GPU for transcoding
I've found that "old" GPUs for transcoding are usually worse than CPU transcoding because they often don't have good codec support. "Old" better be a few generations at worst.
>is there a difference between sata controller and HBA?
Quality of the hardware. Just get an HBA. Save that other pci slot from the graphics card for another network adapter.
>something about using a raid card in IT mode
That's the HBA

>>91035941
>Jellyfin supports archives?
I don't think it does. I've worked around this by using a transparent "fuse" filesystem that provides a new directory structure that shows any archives as folders so they appear unzipped from anything using that filesystem. rar2fs is an example. I've also used fuse filesystems to transcode FLAC -> MP3, I think it's called mp3fs. fuse is pretty neat.

posts.com:
Possibly retarded question but here goes:

Is there any way to run a FreeFileSync-like program WITHIN TrueNAS Core or UNRAID?

Occasionally I like to sync my array with a single disk cold backup. Connect to server, sync, disconnect and put back on the shelf in another room.

Right now my array is a Windows Server ReFS array (lol) (I started with it because Windows was easier for me to understand as I dipped nto this world). Occasionally (every 2-3 months) I attach an external and I use FreeFileSync to update the backup disk. I prefer to run it on the server itself, using remote desktop, rather than running FreeFileSync from a different computer (my laptop), because when I do it locally, anything deleted goes into the proper Recycle Bin on the external drive, but if I do it over the network, files are just completely deleted, they don't go into the Recycle Bin. So then I would have to configure a custom recycle bin within FreeFileSync, and either put that on yet a third drive, or change the folder structure on the bacup drive to accomodate that. Extra layer of complication, extra annoyance.

So anyway, while the Windows Server array has been stable for me for 7 months, everywhere I turn people tell me I'm still playing Russian Roulette with the data, so I'm thinking about TrueNAS Core and ZFS or UNRAID with the data integrity plugin.

But yeah, I would love to plug in a cold single disk from time to time via USB, remote in and manually run a sync from the array to the bacup disk, FreeFileSync-style. So can you run standalone programs within either OS, that can interact with the arrays you have? Or does either OS have any FreeFileSync-style built-in tools for this purpose? Can they even operate / interact with single non-array disks?

>>91033537
>Do I have to now be the sysadmin for a publicly exposed server?
No, it has decent secure defaults.
>Is it more or less secure than my ISP router?
Arguably more secure - from my experience ISP provided devices (modems, routers) have never been patched at all. Unless the vulnerability allowed you to root the device and copy connection secrets to use with your own modem/ONT.
>Also os it better to put OPNsense on something like proxmox or just have it bare metal?
I prefer a standalone router - me and other users stay online even if I put server down for routine "why the fuck does this shit pull 170 watts idle" troubleshooting endeavor. Some people virtualize it on their servers, it's not a bad idea, just keep that issue in mind. Some of them have a spare normal router nearby to plug while they have their server down.
>>91034380
Dell H310 with IT firmware is cheap and good. Add a pair of SFF-8087 mini SAS to 4x SATA cables and it'll work.
Just make sure in the mobo manual that using one of those PCIe slots doesn't disable M.2, usually it's another issue: using secondary M.2 disables two of SATA ports (they share PCIe lanes).

>>91045038
general manipulation, ok so you want to be able to read and write data? generally all types of storage do this. Being able to access it from other computers is also generally how network storage works, you should try using a network storage solution, off the shelf or self made? There's a lot out there, depending on how you use your data. Do you plan to read sequentially? Is the data compressible? Does it need to be encrypted? Do you need redundancy? What if you want more performance? Should you sacrifice performance for redundancy? Do you want snapshots? Should it be available as a drive format, mounted by other computers, or exposed filesystem mounted by other computers? Are they windows, or linux? Do you plan to use advanced ACL features to limit who sees what?

You don't really know what you want so it really doesn't matter what you do.

posts.com:
>>91034380
you dont need a GPU for transcoding and like anon said it's usually a waste of money since the iGPU is way more efficient. anything 8th gen intel with at least a 630 iGPU can do 4k transcoding on the fly.
>i dont know what raid card in IT mode is
it's a raid card (HBA) flashed to pass-thru the drives to the OS instead of doing on-board hardware raid, it's usually your best bet these days in case something goes wrong or you want to migrate, as modern CPUs are more than enough to handle it (see "hardware raid is dead" on YT from level1techs if you want an explanation).
Tho you dont strictly need it. you could fix the SATA ports, or buy a M.2 to SATA adapter with 5 slots, but it might be close to the same price as a decent HBA. check ebay for "HBA IT MODE 8i" and get one that's model 92xx and includes cables. "8i" means it has support for 8 internal drives.

if you get the m.2 sata adapter would let you to get any cheap 10g NIC in the x16 slot just as an option, but probably a waste unless you want to make the box into a router too.

In the EU the FTTH infrastructure is being built by common EU funding and competition of ISPs is mandatory. The level 1 ISPs are the operators, but it was paid by common funds, so they can't gouge prices or anything like that. The consumer market is a free market with everyone having equal access to exchanges and FTTH hubs.
It is as it should be, you don't have private power lines, roads or fresh water infrastructure, do you?

But still, open Ableton now and go back to making dinner. When you come back it will be easier to get into it.
Then just give yourself the task of doing the smallest thing possible, like working for a minute or making a simple riff or something, and then shutting it down.
If you change your mind you can still continue, but start with the intention of just doing the small thing and it will be easier to get a full session going, compared to starting with the intention of doing the bigger task from the start.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91001610
I have this alesis dm7, it takes up maybe 1.2m^2 so not too big. the pads are all a single velocity, no zones for the ride (edge/bell) or snare like fancier kits, though it does detect snare rim separately. The hat pedal is also not quite continuous, only outputs closed/half-open/open afaict. The single crash cymbal does have a choke sensor if you grab it in the right part but it doesn't work in addictive drums by default; might be able to midi map it but haven't yet.
Even with those limitations it's still more flexible than the 6 pad thing. I think you'd need at least 10 zones or to cover basic kit sounds. If you are space constrained you could pick up finger drumming on a small pad like that apk mini or a launchpad or whatever. no drum sticks but can still be satisfying imo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91009780
They work differently outside of adding and subtracting. Subtractive synthesis doesn't give you nearly as much control. In additive you add the frequencies you want individually. In subtraction, you're not controlling specific frequencies, you're just changing the ones that are below or above a certain threshold. If they were opposites, you'd be able to get exactly the same sounds from both.

posts.com:
The American Dream is a concept that has evolved over time and means different things to different people. Historically, it has often been associated with the idea of owning a home and having a family. However, in recent years, some people have re-evaluated what the American Dream means to them, and it has come to encompass different values such as financial stability, career growth, and personal fulfillment.

It is possible to have a family and own a home while also having some free time. It may require careful planning, budgeting, and time management. It's important to set realistic expectations and to be mindful of the trade-offs that come with achieving different goals. Some people may choose to prioritize their career, while others may choose to prioritize their family. It's also important to remember that the concept of "free time" can mean different things to different people, and some people may be satisfied with a more balanced lifestyle that includes time for work and time for family and leisure activities.

Regarding the premise of the West, it is a personal choice and perspective, whether it is worth it or not. It is important to consider one's own values and goals, and to weigh the pros and cons of different lifestyles.

In the end, it's important to remember that the American Dream is not a one-size-fits-all concept and that everyone has their own unique definition of success. It's up to each person to determine what is most important to them and to strive for a balance that works for them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048148
A 3060 can get you to 60FPS in AAAs and 144+ in older/lighter games. You won't be cranking every slider but frankly there's a lot of settings these days that are little more than placebo. Diminishing returns.
A 3060Ti is very roughly 20% faster than the base 3060. Enough to push those sliders to high and maybe even do a little RT with DLSS. Alternatively, enough to push to 75FPS or more if you prefer smoothness over fidelity.
As always, understand that there's going to be some games that just eat graphics cards. Whether due to truly high fidelity or simply by being sloppily made. Best to look up actual benchmarks. The general rule of buying as much GPU power as fits in the budget still applies. Especially in this price range where there's no risk of overspeccing for your monitor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91048314
see >>91048274
A 6650XT is pretty similar to a 3060. Maybe a little faster but nothing to write home about. Whereas the 6700-6750XT straddle the 3060Ti. I think of those I'd take the 67*0XT so long as you're not seriously compromising the rest of the build by doing so. It's easy enough to upgrade a card later whereas your only upgrade path on AM4 is the X3D. A fine CPU but not a huge uplift from a 5700X outside of certain games.

>How much of a difference does VRAM do, i.e from 8GB to 12GB
At 1440p not much. 8GB is "enough" right now so long as you're not going crazy with mods or texture packs. Definitely better to have 12 though.

To sum up:
>If you're on a very tight budget
66*0XT
>If you upgrade cards frequently
6700
>If you don't
67*0XT

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Terry Lambert
>Apple Core OS Kernel Team; technical lead on several projects over 8 years

What goes into making an OS to be Unix compliant certified?

A lot.

I was the tech lead at Apple for making Mac OS X pass UNIX certification, and it was done to get Apple out of a $200M lawsuit filed by The Open Group, for use of the UNIX™ trademark in advertising.

The lawsuit was filed because the owner of Mac OS X Server kept putting “UNIX” on the web site, and all other marketing collateral for the Server product.

The options were:

Make Mac OS X actually UNIX™, to defang the lawsuit; this would also make The Open Group industry relevant, when at the time they were losing a lot of that to Linux’ increasing popularity — which is why it was an option on the table at all
Buy The Open Group for about a billion dollars so that Apple could freely use the Trademark to describe a power cord, if they wanted to; this would not get them out of existing contractual obligations with Sun Microsystems, IBM, and others, who had already licensed the use of the trademark, however

I was asked if I could lead a team to do #1. I said “Yes, under the condition that I could use the compliance project as a hammer to force other parts of the organization to make changes in their own code base, and that I could play it rather loose with commit rules regarding what it said in the bugs database for a given code change, and what the given code change actually did, in addition to what it said in the bugs database”.

I was given the “go”.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91046273

And so we ran the compliance test suite against the existing Mac OS source base, and it immediately errored out because of the header files.

And Ed Moy and I made a two line change that moved a type definition from <stdio.h> to where it was supposed to be, instead. One line of change in <stdio.h>, and another in the file the type was actually supposed to be located in.

And we ran the tests again, and one of the header file errors in the tests went away.

So we did a “world build”, where everything that was in Mac OS X, including iTunes, got rebuilt.

That — essentially, one line change — broke 152 (from memory; that number sticks up, but it might have only been 137) projects failed to build.

Including iTunes.

And so Ed and I went through, and fixed every single one of those projects to build with the change, or without the change.

And we did another “world build”, and everything built.

Yes, we had access to all of Apple’s source code, at that point in the game.

And so we submitted high priority bug fixes to the projects, some of which downgraded the priority immediately, and some of which they simply fixed, since we had provided them with the patch already.

And then the VP of engineering, Bertrand Serlet, re-escalated the priority on the ones which had been downgraded.

And we committed the header file changes.

At this point, we had to go back, and reassess the feasibility of the whole project.

Ed and I felt it was doable in the timeframe, given the preconditions I had already placed on the project.

Ed was willing to say anything directly.

I said “yes”, putting my job on the line, were we given the “go”.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91046285

It escalated up to Steve.

We were given the “go”.

It was, after all, saving Apple either $1 billion or $200 million plus revamping all of the Mac OS X Server marketing collateral, after all.

We were promised 1/10th of the $200 million, or $20 million in stock, on completion. $10 million to me, $5 million to Ed, and $5 million to Karen Crippes, who was looking for a home in Mac OS X development, I knew was an amazing engineer, and who could be roped into being technical liaison and periodically kicking off the tests and complaining to Ed and I about things not passing.

I got the $10 million, because it was going to be my job on the line, and potentially, my ability to work in industry at a high level, ever again, in the future.

Also, the tech lead has to fix anything no one else fixes, or no one else can fix, because they are the DRI (Directly Responsible Individual).

I also wasn’t just tech lead; I was de facto project manager.

I wore a lot of hats.

It was going to be long slog.

I had estimated a year, for a team of 5 individuals: the three mousekateers (not a misspelling), two contractors — one for mostly user space code; that was Len Lattanzi, and one for full time test automation and bug filing, Jaime Delgadillo, who also contributed patches, where possible.

We had two more temporary contractors; one for tools compliance, and one for the man pages.

And then anyone we could rope in from elsewhere in Apple, on a case by case basis, for a short term.

This was mostly to make sure they were invested in the project; we didn’t actually need them to write code.

you can choose to create a password required to get into the iPhone. If for some reason you enter the wrong password more than 6 times it "disables" the iPhone so that it is inaccessible and has to be wiped to factory settings in order to be used. And if that happens any photos/data that isn't backed up is lost forever. I never knew that was what happened and I figured I would get more than 6 attempts at the password. Even though I remember the password now I can't find anyway to save the data on the phone. I just hadn't used the phone in weeks and tried to open it while a bit drunk and entered the wrong code, that's how I got it disabled. If I would have known this is what happens I would have waited and made sure I had the right code. Sucks man I lost hours of really good videos and lots of voice memos with song ideas in them.

posts.com:
I dunno if this was already a thing but I had chatgpt make a little script to it possible to screenshot the whole chat. I'm sure someone that knows what they're doing could eliminate the need to set the size but, here it is. scroll up to load all first.

// ==UserScript==
// @name         Scrollbar Modify
// @namespace    http://tampermonkey.net/
// @version      0.1
// @description  A Tampermonkey script to change the height and visibility of the scrollbar
// @author       Your Name
// @match        https://beta.character.ai/chat*
// @grant        none
// ==/UserScript==


(function() {
    'use strict';

    // Create button
    var btn = document.createElement("BUTTON");
    btn.innerHTML = "Set Height";
    btn.style.position = "fixed";
    btn.style.bottom = "20px";
    btn.style.left = "20px";
    document.body.appendChild(btn);

    // Create Input Box
    var input = document.createElement("INPUT");
    input.setAttribute("type", "text");
    input.style.position = "fixed";
    input.style.bottom = "60px";
    input.style.left = "20px";
    input.style.width = "90px";
    input.style.height = "30px";
    input.placeholder = "height";
    document.body.appendChild(input);

    // Add click event to button
    btn.addEventListener("click", function() {
        var scrollbar = document.getElementById("scrollBar");
        scrollbar.style.height = input.value + "px";
        scrollbar.style.overflow = "visible";
    });

    // Create Revert button
    var btnRevert = document.createElement("BUTTON");
    btnRevert.innerHTML = "Revert Height";
    btnRevert.style.position = "fixed";
    btnRevert.style.bottom = "20px";
    btnRevert.style.left = "160px";
    document.body.appendChild(btnRevert);

    // Add click event to Revert button
    btnRevert.addEventListener("click", function() {
        var scrollbar = document.getElementById("scrollBar");
        scrollbar.style.height = "826px";
        scrollbar.style.overflow = "auto";
    });
})();

Chat mode just has different formatting from Kobold's normal story mode but it's basically the same thing. All it does is predict what text should be created next. I know NAI has stop sequences that will force the AI to stop generating if it tries to generate a certain token, (for example, telling the AI to stop when it tries to generate "You:"). Linux mobile is nowhere near ready for mainstream adoption, and I’m only sticking with mine because I don’t want to spend money on another phone.

Saw this thread today, I whant to share it again
It's an OS aiming for high quality and
simplicity.

It has a functional package manager, reproducible ports, a top-down build system (redo djb), its own POSIX coreutils (with more tools and atomicity). All built using its own safe system programming library instead of the std libc.

Main Page: https://eltaninos.org/
FAQ: https://eltaninos.org/?faq
Roadmap: https://eltaninos.org/?roadmap
News: https://eltaninos.org/?blog/index
Community: https://eltaninos.org/?community/index

Glacies is a linux distribution using the Linux kernel and the Eltanin userland. It uses musl as libc, an advanced init system (s6 and s6-rc), and a high quality display server (arcan).

For now everything is in quite early stage, I'm just gathering feedback to expand the FAQ and relevant info, maybe expand the community too (considering using discord too, it seems many uses it).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91025587
Usually when people talk about a standard that has multiple different classifications and revisions they make a point of stating the exact one rather than referring to the family as a whole. That helps to remove ambiguity and puts everyone on the same page so that they know clearly what the wiring is rated for.
If you don't do that people are going to assume you're talking about the most common revision that's in use (Cat5e).

People like OP aren't very difficult to understand and the psychiatric literature is very detailed about them. In this age of increasing surveillance, the growing threat are the stalkers with ulterior motives who wantt to gain something from monitoring you.

OP is a stalker with no explicit ulterior motive who is satisfied by the simple sight of people living their lives. He probably finds comfort in observing the routines of others. He probably have some hibernating psychological and emotional issues whether he acknowledges it or not. He most likely has a feeling that his own life lacks something or in the worst cases, the stalker feels so lonesome and detached from other humans that he develops a curiosity toward others.

It starts to get dark when the stalker has traits like an anti-social personality disorder or a severe introverse (which is often the case). In these situations his life slowly starts to revolve around the routine of one or two persons and he gets an ego boost by playing the detective.At the end of the day, he will always get an impulse to get closer to what i can only describe now as his victim.

I get you anon, I like that too. Probably because of some of the reasons other anons have been accusing you of being motivated by instead of whatever your reasons are, but I think know what you're looking for. Best way to experience this is to walk around in a crowded public place. Look for small groups of people: usually energetic groups of young adults are what you're looking for, but whatever the case good groups will be absorbed in their own conversation and activities, so they won't notice or care that you're following them. You can spend hours listening to their natural conversations this way, it's very nice. Even better is if you live somewhere sunny, since sunglasses allow you to watch without having to use your peripheral vision all the time. If you have clip on sunglasses that are slightly too large and the sun is in the right position you can even watch them with your back facing towards them, and you can hold up your phone in front of you on maps or something. This way, they won't notice even if they pass very close to you. I would like to be able to use cameras and microphones, (my fantasy would be a network of them throughout a city, but none in private places like homes etc.) but i'd be too worried that someone would notice and i'd get caught.
